channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Plans Military Drills in Eastern Europe
item.description: The moves in Poland and Estonia are part of a broader effort to strengthen NATO’s air, sea and land presence in the region in response to Russia’s military actions in and near Ukraine.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
item.description: A reminder that the invisible hand of the United States government is at work in ways unlike anything seen in typical courtrooms.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO

item.title: In Pistorius Trial, Critics See a Justice System Favoring the Rich and Famous
item.description: The murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter has highlighted the wide gap between celebrity justice and the treatment meted out to ordinary South Africans.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at his murder trial on Thursday in Pretoria, South Africa. He was granted bail last year on lenient conditions.

item.title: Italian Bank Proposes Increased Stock Offering
item.description: The plan to issue $6.9 billion in new stock comes as the bank fights to avoid nationalization and braces for stress tests of its balance sheet by European regulators.
item.category: Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: The headquarters of Monte dei Paschi in Siena, Italy. The bank, Italy’s third largest, must begin repaying a European bailout.

item.title: World Briefing: Algerian President Wins a Fourth Term
item.description: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has won a fourth term as Algeria’s leader, receiving 81.5 percent of the vote, officials said Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By AMIR JALAL ZERDOUMI

item.title: World Briefing: Viral Disease Spreads to Southeast Asia
item.description: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Paper Shows U.S.-Flagged Plane in Iran Has Ties to Ghana
item.description: The ownership ties between a Utah bank and a Ghanaian company raise questions about the role of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG

item.title: Snowden Defends Query to Putin on Surveillance
item.description: Edward J. Snowden expressed surprise at criticism directed toward him, insisting that he had been trying to hold Russia’s government to account over its surveillance practices, as he did with the Obama administration.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JOHN HARNEY

item.title: Pro-Russian Insurgents Balk at Terms of Pact in Ukraine
item.description: A U.S.-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat but appeared to arrest, at least temporarily, the momentum of separatist unrest in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Ex-Marine Held in Iran Asks Official for Help
item.description: Amir Hekmati, an American incarcerated in Iran since August 2011, recently wrote to its foreign minister seeking help in gaining his release.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Obama Signs Bill That Bars Iran’s Envoy
item.description: President Obama signed a bill into law on Friday that would prohibit anyone who has engaged in espionage or terrorism against the United States from obtaining a visa to enter the country as a representative to the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
item.description: The Sherpas were at an altitude of about 19,000 feet when the avalanche hit. At least 12 died, and four missing.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and GRAHAM BOWLEY
item.media:description: Mount Everest in 2009. An avalanche swept down a slope of Mount Everest on Friday, killing guides.

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine Seeks Inquiry Into Killings
item.description: Ukraine has asked the International Criminal Court to investigate the deaths of civilians on its territory that occurred from Nov. 21, 2013, to Feb. 22, covering the period when more than 100 people were killed during antigovernment protests.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Memo From Berlin: Twin Shocks Shake Foundation of German Power
item.description: Revelations of American spying and the crisis in Ukraine have left Germany feeling that the established rules of the 21st century have been broken.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk of Ukraine, left, with the German foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, last month.

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Rattles Mexico, Shakes Buildings
item.description: A powerful earthquake shook Mexico on Friday, damaging more than 100 homes in the southwestern state of Guerrero and opening cracks in some buildings but there were no reports of deaths.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: People evacuated buildings after a magnitude 7.5 earthquake shook Mexico City on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: Turkish Women Use Twitter to Fight Sexual Harassment
item.description: Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: What Is Putin’s ‘New Russia’?
item.description: In a Q. and A. session, President Vladimir V. Putin referred repeatedly to southeastern Ukraine as “Novorossiya,” a historical term meaning “New Russia.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: The Lede: Snowden Defends His Part in Putin Forum
item.description: One day after he took part in a stage-managed forum with President Vladimir Putin on Russian state television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden defended his participation.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: Program to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons Is 75% Complete, Group Says
item.description: An official from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said Syria might not finish the job by a revised deadline of April 27, but might do so soon after.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
item.description: The captain, Lee Jun-seok, 69, was charged with abandoning the boat and its passengers at a time of crisis, among other counts, according to prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:credit: South Korean Coast Guard, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The Korean ferry's captain, Lee Jun-seok, was seen being rescued from the sinking vessel on Wednesday.

item.title: Chinese Official Urges Russia and Central Asian Allies to Control Internet
item.description: Guo Shengkun, China’s minister of public security, said that Russia and Central Asian countries must prevent “external forces” from trying to overthrow governments and provoke revolutions.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Russian Opposition Figure Faces Accusations of Libel
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, is accused of calling a Moscow politician a “drug addict,” a charge he denies.
item.dc:creator: By NOAH SNEIDER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 18
item.description: A procession in Kolkata, West Bengal, to mark the occasion of Good Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Japan Plans to Resume Whaling Program, With Changes to Address Court Concerns
item.description: Japan officials said the whaling, which they say is for research, would be redesigned to address objections raised by an international court.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A Japanese whaling vessel. Earlier this month, Japan canceled this year’s hunt after a ruling by the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
